a b s t r a c t
A novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial was synthesized by ion irradiation of a CeSiC coaxial nanotube. The hybrid consisted of one-dimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks with diameters less than 50 nm and cylindrical multiwalled carbon nanotubes inside an amorphous SiC tubular layer. A sudden emergence of new continuous graphitic layers in the microstructure were observed by in situ transmission electron microscopy following ion irradiation, where these layers were perpendicular to the nanotube's length direction. The SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube became amorphous, also due to the ion irradiation, although the critical amorphization dose was higher than that for bulk SiC. Most remarkably, the carbon layer remained crystalline, even after an irradiation dose higher than 20 dpa (displacement per atom). Such results show that these carbon layers possess better resistance against amorphization when subjected to ion irradiation than the SiC layers in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube. The lattice plane spacing of the carbon layer increases up to the point when irradiation damage lead to the complete amorphization of SiC crystals, after which it starts to decrease. This demonstrates that the carbon layer experiences high compression stress during ion irradiation. Thus, the ion irradiation of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes gives rise to a novel development of the microstructure and can be considered as one of the new synthetic processes for making novel carbon nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Silicon carbide (SiC) is one of the crucial wide-bandgap semiconductors and is also a structural material that can be used under high temperatures [1,2]. It is known however, that one-dimensional nanomaterials, such as nanowires, nanorods, and nanotubes possess new properties different from those of their bulk materials due to having intriguing geometries and a nanometer size [3,4]. Hitherto, we have succeeded in synthesizing single-phase SiC nanotubes and CeSiC coaxial nanotubes, in which multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were coated with a SiC layer by heat treatment of MWCNTs with Si powder in a vacuum [5,6]. In situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to observe microstructural developments of single-phase SiC nanotubes under ion irradiation, where the results clearly differed from those of bulk

SiC [7]. The carbon and SiC layers in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes may therefore also exhibit novel microstructural developments under ion irradiation. This study systematically investigate microstructural development of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes under ion irradiation using in situ TEM observation.
A new carbon nanomaterial with its graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction had previously been produced inside the amorphous SiC tubular layer by ion irradiation of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes [8]. It is well known that carbon atoms form many distinct allotropes, such as carbine, graphite, and diamond, because they exist in three states according to sp-, sp2-and sp3-hybridization of their valence orbitals [9,10]. Moreover, since the 1980s, many other allotropes of carbon nanomaterials have been discovered, such as fullerenes by Kroto et al., in 1985 [11], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) by Iijima in 1991 [12], and graphene by Novoselov et al., in 2004 [13]. Carbon nanomaterials also exhibit outstanding properties compared with bulk graphite because of their intriguing geometries and nanometer size [14,15]. At the nano-scale carbon nanomaterials possess physical properties that
are very dependent on their atomic structure. Carbon nanofibers and MWCNTs have been reported to not only consist of typical cylindrical-type nanotubes, but also of other types such as cupstacked-type [16], bamboo-type [17], nano-bell-type [18], nanonecklace-type [19], and pot-shaped-type [20], as well as nanocoils [21], platelet nanofibers [22,23], and herringbone nanofibers [24,25]. Recently, a carbon nanobelt, consisting of a closed loop of fully fused edge-sharing benzene rings, has been synthesized for the first time since being proposed as a potentially revolutionary molecule in chemistry over 60 years ago [26]. A novel carbon nanocomposite comprising multilayered graphene and aligned MWCNTs has also been produced [27]. Furthermore, Nasibulin et al. have syntehsized new hybrid carbon nanomaterials, termed “nanobuds,” that combine fullerenes and single-walled CNTs (SWCNTs) into a single structure in which the fullerenes are covalently bonded to the outer surface of the SWCNTs [28]. The synthesis of graphene nanoribbons encapsulated in SWCNTs have also been reported [29]. These novel-structured and hybrid carbon nanomaterials are expected to demonstrate superior physical properties compared to typical carbon nanomaterials. It is therefore necessary to synthesize those carbon nanomaterials with novel structures in order to develop and broaden the applications of carbon nanomaterials. This study presents a successful synthesis and formation mechanism of a novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial, consisting of one-dimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks and cylindrical MWCNTs inside amorphous SiC nanotubes.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
Cup-stacked MWCNTs (GSI creos Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) and typical cylindrical MWCNTs (Sigma-Aldrich Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) were used as the template materials. Typical TEM images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of these obtained cylindrical MWCNTs and cup-stackedMWCNTs are shown in Figs. S1 and S2. A cylindrical MWCNT had its graphitic shells almost parallel to the nanotube length direction. In contrast, the carbon layer in the cup-stacked MWCNT was separated into two regions. The outer carbon layer had its graphitic shells almost parallel to the nanotube length direction; the same for the cylindrical MWCNTs. The graphitic shells in the inner carbon layer were however inclined slightly to the radial direction as shown in Fig. S2 (d). The CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were synthesized by heat treatment of MWCNTs and Si powder without direct contact with each other at 1200 C for 100 h in a vacuum of 5 10 4 Pa [5,6]. The samples heated at the above conditions included many unreacted MWCNTs besides the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes. Therefore, the samples were then heated at 700 C for 2 h in air in order to eliminate unreacted MWCNTs [5,6]. The CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were next ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol for 20min after which they were deposited on a molybdenum grid TEM sample holder with a holey-carbon layer, followed by drying at room temperature. The deposited coaxial nanotubes were then irradiated with 200-keV Siþ ions at room temperature by a 400-kV ion implanter in a TEM instrument (Model JEM-4000FX, JEOL Ltd., Akishima, Japan) operating at 400 kV. The in situ TEM observation under ion irradiation was performed at the Takasaki Ion Accelerators for Advanced Radiation Application (TIARA) facility in the National Institutes for Quantum and Radiological Science and Technology in Japan. The CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were irradiated with both 200 keV Si ions and 400 keV electrons simultaneously in the TEM instrument. The projected ranges of 200-keV Si ions in the SiC and C targets were estimated to be approximately 177 and 221 nm using a SRIM 2008 program [30]. These results show that almost all irradiated Si ions had integrally transpierced the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes. The ion fluence was up to 1.1 1021 ions/m2,
and the corresponding irradiation damage (in terms of displacement per atom; dpa) for the SiC and carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes was estimated by SRIM 2008 to be 28.4 and 26.6 dpa, respectively. The threshold displacement energies in this study were adapted to be 20 eV for C and 40 eV for Si in SiC and 30 eV for C in graphite [31]. The extensive microstructural developments to the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes before and after ion irradiation were observed by TEM (Model 2100F, JEOL Ltd., Akishima, Japan) operating at 200 kV.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text:
3.1. Microstructural development of a CeSiC coaxial nanotube from a cup-stacked MWCNT
Low-magnification and high-resolution (HR) TEM images of a CeSiC coaxial nanotube synthesized from a cup-stacked MWCNT before ion irradiation are shown in Fig. 1; the SAED pattern of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube being also shown. The low-magnification TEM image shown in Fig. 1(a), estimated the average outer and inner diameters of the nanotube to be 183.7 ± 7.0 and 25.3± 1.8 nm, respectively. The SAED and HR-TEM images indicate that the SiC of the nanotube's outer layer was comprised of polycrystals. The average thickness of the SiC layer was 21.0± 4.8 nm. The carbon of the nanotube's inner layer was separated into two regions. One had its graphitic shells almost parallel to the nanotube length direction, as in the cylindrical MWCNTs shown in Fig. 1(b). The graphitic shells in the inner region, however, inclined slightly to the radial direction, as shown in Fig. 1(c). The average bend angle was 18.5± 4.1 . The average thickness of latter region was 7.7± 1.1 nm.
A sequence of observed TEM images and SAED patterns of the same CeSiC coaxial nanotube obtained by the TEM equipped with an ion implanter are shown in Fig. 2. The CeSiC coaxial nanotube was irradiated by up to 9.1 1020 ions/m2. The corresponding irradiation damage for the SiC and carbon layers in CeSiC coaxial
nanotube were estimated as 23.8 and 22.3 dpa respectively, by the SRIM 2008 program. The SAED patterns demonstrated a decreasing degree of crystallinity in the nanotube's SiC layer with increasing irradiation damage. The SiC crystals became entirely amorphized when the ion fluence was 7.2 1019 ions/m2. In contrast, the graphite (002) spots ascribed to the nanotube's carbon layer can be clearly observed, even after ion irradiation of up to 9.1 1020 ions/ m2, indicating that the crystallinity of the carbon layer remained, despite the complete amorphization of the SiC layer. Moreover, the new graphite (002) spots emerged suddenly at an angle tilted 90 to the original graphite (002) spots. In addition to the graphite (002) spots that remained, even after ion irradiation, new graphite (002) spots were observed at an angle tilted 90 to the original graphite (002) spots. HR-TEM images clearly exhibit original graphitic shells almost parallel to the nanotube length direction, but the basal planes appear damaged and broken into small segments, shown in Fig. 3(b). In addition, new graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction were produced in the center part of the nanotube, shown in Fig. 3(d). The distortion of the basal plane in the new graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction was clearly smaller than for the original graphitic shells that were parallel to the nanotube length direction.
3.2. Microstructural development of CeSiC coaxial nanotube from a typical cylindrical MWCNT
Low-magnification and HR-TEM images and SAED pattern of a CeSiC coaxial nanotube synthesized from a cylindrical-type MWCNT, before ion irradiation, are shown in Fig. 4. According to the low-magnification TEM image, the average outer and inner diameters were estimated as 191.2± 29.5 and 24.6± 9.1 nm, respectively. The SAED and HR-TEM images reveal that the SiC layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube was polycrystalline. The average thickness of the SiC layer was 37.3± 12.9 nm. The carbon layer consisted of only one region whose graphitic shells were almost parallel to the nanotube length direction; unlike the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from the cup-stacked MWCNTs. The CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from the cylindrical-type MWCNTs had almost the same dimensions, such as their outer and inner diameters, compared to those from cup-stackedMWCNTs. However, the thickness of the SiC layer was much larger.
The low-magnification and HR-TEM images and SAED pattern of
the same CeSiC coaxial nanotube from a typical cylindrical MWCNTs, after irradiation at up to 1.1 1021 ions/m2, are shown in Fig. 5. The corresponding irradiation damage to the SiC and carbon layers in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube were estimated as 28.4 and 26.6 dpa by the SRIM 2008. The average outer diameter was estimated as 254.8± 33.4 nm from the low-magnification TEM image where it had increased 1.3 times more than before ion irradiation. After ion irradiation, the tube length had decreased 0.78 times and the inner diameter disappeared. The degree of crystallinity in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube's SiC layer decreased with increasing irradiation damage, and this SiC layer became entirely amorphized by ion irradiation at 8.0 1019 ions/m2, as demonstrated by in situ TEM in Fig. S1. Such changes in dimension and crystallinity by ion irradiation are consistent with those of the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from cup-stacked MWCNTs. The average thickness of the SiC layer was estimated as 70.7± 17.8 nm and had increased approximately 1.9 times after ion irradiation. Furthermore, the spots ascribed to the SiC layer had transformed into a hazy halo ring as seen in the SAED patterns following ion irradiation. The graphite (002) spots were faintly observed, even after an irradiation of 1.1 1021 ions/ m2. However, any new graphite (002) spots tilted by 90 to the original spots did not appear. The HR-TEM images indicate that an amorphous structure occurred in the wide carbon layer, while the finite-sized crystalline regions only partially remained; Fig. 5(b) and (c).

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
4.1. Configuration changes of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes
The change ratios of outer and inner diameters in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs were estimated from the low-magnification TEM images; Fig, 6. They indicate that the nanotube's outer diameter increased monotonically during the course of ion irradiation. However, the inner diameter decreased,
with the interior hole finally disappearing at an irradiation damage level of 4.5 1020 ions/m2. After irradiation, the outer diameter of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from a typical cylindrical MWCNT also increased, while its inner diameter disappeared; the same holding true for the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from a cup-stacked MWCNT; Figs. 4 and 5, and S3.
For the SiC nanotubes, the outer and inner diameters increased until the SiC crystals became entirely amorphous due to increasing disorder of the SiC crystals and a decreased density [7]. After complete amorphization of the SiC crystals, both diameters of the SiC nanotubes had decreased to relieve the residual stress in the SiC layer [7]. However, in CeSiC coaxial nanotubes, the outer diameter increased monotonically, while the inner diameter decreased. The basal planes in graphite are broken into small segments by irradiation with neutrons, electrons, or ions where the segment size decreases with increasing irradiation fluence [32,33]. Point defects, such as vacancies and interstitial atoms, were generated by the irradiation. Interstitial atoms among basal planes, produced interlayer interstitial clusters, which resulted in an expansion perpendicular to the basal planes. In contract, collapsing vacancies into the line defects led to contraction parallel to the basal planes [34,35]. In MWCNTs, point defects were induced, and the crystallinity disorder was increased by irradiation; this also applying to graphite [36,37]. Therefore, irradiation results in expansion of basal planes in MWCNTs in the radial direction, while the length becomes shortened in MWCNTs.
Banharg et al. reported that the outer diameter of MWCNTs decreases by a loss of atoms because of the knocking out and sputtering of C atoms from its surface [38]. Nevertheless, any sputtering of C atoms from the carbon layer's outer surface in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube hardly occurred in this study, because the SiC layer was sheathed onto the carbon layer. The outer diameter of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube increased, and the inner diameter decreased with increasing the irradiation fluence, because expansion of the carbon layer in the radial direction was greater than the contraction of the SiC layer's diameter. Therefore after ion irradiation, a tensile stress acted on the SiC layer, whereas compression stress accrued on the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube.
The change ratio of nanotube length in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from cup-stacked MWCNTs and typical cylindrical MWCNTs were 0.63± 0.03 nm and 0.78± 0.04 nm, respectively. These values were much smaller than for a SiC nanotube (0.93) [7]. As aforementioned in graphite, irradiation results in a swelling perpendicular to the basal planes and a shrinkage parallel to the basal planes [34,35]. The ion irradiation used in this study also led to manifest shrinkage parallel to the nanotube length direction in the carbon layer of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube as well as for
graphite. Therefore, irradiation caused the lengths of the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes to be much more retracted than those of the SiC nanotubes. Wall thicknesses of SiC nanotube have been reported to swell approximately 1.3 times upon ion irradiation at room temperature [7]. Our study found that the thickness of the SiC layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube, from both cup-stacked MWCNT and from a typical cylindrical MWCNT, had swelled approximately 1.5 and 1.9 times after the irradiation, respectively. Despite the increased inner and outer diameters of the SiC layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube, the increasing rate of SiC layer thickness in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube was larger than that of the SiC nanotube. The reason is plainly to conserve volume, because the CeSiC coaxial nanotube was shortened much more than the SiC nanotube following ion irradiation.
4.2. Crystallinity changes of crystals in CeSiC coaxial nanotubes
It has been known that both knock-on damage and ionizing radiation may cause microstructural changes such as a crystallinity change in SiC and graphite subjectd to ion irradiation. The electronic stopping powers (Se), in the carbon and SiC layer of CeSiC coaxial nanotube under 200 keV Siþ ion irradiation, are estimated to be approximately 0.72 and 0.68 keV/nm respectively, by the SRIM 2008 program. Zinkle et al. have reported that the threshold Se for microstructural change in SiC is> 34 keV/nm [39]. Liu et al. have reported that structural transformation on graphite's original surface is due to electronic energy loss processes occurring above a critical threshold of 7.3 keV/nm [40]. Therefore, no microstructural change in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes can occur from the ionizing radiation used in this study because of a much smaller Se under 200 keV Si ion irradiation. The displacement damage in our study of the carbon and SiC layers in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes under the ion irradiation is now discussed.
SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from cup-stacked MWCNTs and from typical cylindrical MWCNTs were entirely amorphized by ion irradiation at 7.2 1019 and 8.0 1019 ions/m2, respectively. The corresponding irradiation damages to the SiC layer, as estimated by the SRIM 2008 [30], were 1.9 and 2.1 dpa. The CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were irradiatedwith both Si ions and 400- keV electrons simultaneous because in situ TEMwas used under ion irradiation in this study. It was previously reported that any consequences of 400-keV electrons irradiation on the amorphization of SiC crystals in SiC nanotubes can be disregarded [7]. There have also beenmany reports on the effect of irradiation on the amorphization of bulk SiC [41e43]. The critical doses required to amorphize bulk SiC by ion irradiation were 0.4e1.0 dpa at room temperature as found in previous studies [41e43]. The critical amorphization doses for SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were however larger compared to those from the previous studies on bulk SiC [41e43]. The reason is considered to be that the induced point defects, arising from the irradiation, may diffuse and be released readily from the surface and grain boundaries in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes because the nanotubes have a larger specific surface area due to their nano-size and tubular form. However, the critical amorphization doses for SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were smaller than that in a SiC nanotube (2.9 dpa) [7]. As the inner surface of the SiC layer is in contact with the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube, it would therefore be difficult to release the induced point defects from the inner surface of the SiC layer when compared with the SiC nanotube. On the contrary, it may be possible that these induced point defects in the carbon layer during ion irradiation diffuse to the SiC layer from the inner surface. Therefore, the critical amorphization doses of SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes are smaller compared to that in the SiC nanotube.
SiC possesses an excellent irradiation tolerance, such as crystallinity and configuration stabilities under irradiation [44]. Niwase et al. have reported that graphite was readily amorphized by D or He ion irradiation at a critical dose of less than 1 dpa at room temperatures [45]. In our study, both SiC and carbon layers in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from both cup-stacked MWCNTs and typical cylindrical MWCNTs were irradiated up to the point where irradiation damage was higher than 20 dpa at room temperature, respectively. The SiC layers naturally amorphized, although the SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes had a larger critical amorphization dose than that in bulk SiC. The graphite (002) spots ascribed to the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs were distinctly maintained, even after an irradiation of 22.3 dpa had been applied to the carbon layer, as shown in Fig. 3(e). Furthermore, new graphitic shells, perpendicular to the nanotube length direction, were suddenly formed in the center part of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from the cup-stacked MWCNTs after irradiation; Fig. 3(d). These newly formed graphitic shells were distributed uniformly over almost the entire nanotube length direction. However, those in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from typical cylindrical MWCNTs were only faintly observed, even after an irradiation of 26.6 dpa for the carbon layer; as shown in Fig. 5(d). Remarkably, these results confirmed that the carbon layers remained crystalline, even when an irradiation dose exceeded 20 dpa. This shows that the carbon layer possesses better resistance against amorphization upon irradiation compared with the SiC layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes. Such an outcome is however not consistent with many previous studies. The increasing resistance to amorphization in the carbon layer of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube was due to the SiC layer sheathing the carbon layer. The SiC coating layers prevented C atoms from sputtering on the carbon layer's outer surface. In addition, a compression stress, attributed to the configuration change of the SiC layer during irradiation, is generated in the carbon layer. Because the volume of crystalline carbon is smaller than that of amorphous carbon, the crystalline carbon may be more stable than amorphous carbon due to a buffering of the compression stress. These effects thus enhance the resistance against amorphization of the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube.
The angle between the center of SAED and both edges of the graphite (002) spots is defined as the spreading angle in this study; shown in Fig. 7. The spreading angles before and after ion irradiation are shown in Table 1. The spreading angle has been shown to have the angle of distortion of the basal plane in the nanotube length direction [46]. We found that the spreading angle of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from typical cylindrical MWCNTs was increased by ion irradiation. This leads to increasing distortion of the graphitic shells by the ion irradiation. However, in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs, the spreading angle after irradiation was smaller than that it was before. The HR-TEM images in Figs. 1(b) and Fig. 3(b), show that this result does not lead to decreasing distortion of the graphitic shells after irradiation.
The reason is considered to be that the inner slightly inclined graphitic shells have been tilted perpendicular to the nanotube length direction. Therefore, new graphite (002) spots appeared at an angle tilted 90 to the original graphite (002) spots. Almost the same spreading angles were observed for graphitic shells, parallel to the nanotube length direction, after irradiation of the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from typical cylindrical MWCNTs and cupstacked MWCNTs; as shown in Table 1. It thereby follows that almost the same degree of distortion was induced in graphitic shells after irradiation, regardless of the type of MWCNTs. However, the spreading angle of newly produced graphite spots was smaller than that of the original graphite spots in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from the cup-stacked MWCNTs. This shows that the newly produced carbon layer had a smaller degree of distortion in the graphitic shells compared with that in the original carbon layer, even after irradiation. This result is consistent with the HR-TEM images in Figs. 1(b) and Fig. 3(d).
4.3. Lattice plane spacing changes of carbon crystals in CeSiC coaxial nanotubes
The lattice plane spacing of graphitic shells can be estimated from the SAED patterns. The relationships between the ion fluence and the lattice plane spacing of graphitic shells in both the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs and from typical cylindrical MWCNTs after ion irradiation are shown in Fig. 8. The lattice plane spacing of (002) graphite (0.335 nm) is also shown in Fig. 8. Prior to ion irradiation, the lattice plane spacings of graphitic shells in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from cup-stacked MWCNTs and from typical cylindrical MWCNTs were estimated as 0.381 and 0.359 nm, respectively. Saito et al. reported that the lattice plane spacing of graphitic sheets in MWCNTs are larger by a few percent than those in graphite [47]. However, the values found in this study are much higher than the lattice plane spacing of (002) graphite. This indicates that the graphitic shells in both CeSiC coaxial nanotubes originally had a number of point defects compared with graphite. The disorder in the carbon layer increased with increasing ion fluence because the induced defects had accumulated. Therefore, the lattice plane spacing of the graphitic shell in both CeSiC coaxial nanotubes increased with increasing the ion fluence. Surprisingly, they started to decrease to 0.399 and 0.395 nm after irradiation damage of 6.4 1019 and 8.0 1019 ions/m2 in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes from cup-stacked MWCNTs and from typical cylindrical MWCNTs, respectively. In general, the lattice plane spacing of MWCNT increases monotonically and is saturated by irradiation because of the accumulated induced point defects [48]. Therefore, the tendency for changes in lattice plane spacing in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube upon irradiation is counterintuitive. That the ion fluence starts to decrease the lattice plane spacing of graphitic shells, corresponds well to that of the entire amorphization of SiC crystals in both CeSiC coaxial nanotubes. A previous study reported that the inner and outer diameters of a SiC nanotube started to decrease just after the complete amorphization of SiC crystals [7]. However, the outer diameters of both CeSiC coaxial nanotubes increased monotonically, regardless of the ion fluence. It is, therefore, considered that compression stress started to accrue on the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube just after the complete amorphization of SiC crystals. These findings imply that the lattice plane spacing of graphitic shells decreases just after the complete amorphization of SiC crystals.
However, new graphitic shells, perpendicular to the nanotube length direction, were suddenly formed in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs after irradiation. The lattice plane spacing of the newly produced graphitic shells was 0.339± 0.001 nm and smaller than that parallel to the nanotube
length direction before ion irradiation; having almost the same value as graphite. The HR-TEM image in Fig. 3(d) indicates that the basal planes in graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction were slightly rippled, thereby demonstrating that the newly produced graphitic shells had a favorable crystallinity.
The lattice plane spacing of graphitic shells parallel to the nanotube length direction decreased from 0.424 nm to 0.399 nm in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs, and from 0.414 nm to 0.395 nm in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from typical cylindrical MWCNTs during irradiation. The strain, ε, of the carbon layer induced by the decrease of lattice plane spacing was 0.0591 and 0.0458 respectively. The stressestrain relationship of ceramics in the linear elastic range is often expressed by the following equation [49]:
sc¼ Eε (1)
Where sc is stress, and E is elastic modulus. Palaci et al. have reported that the radial elastic modulus of CNTs increases acutely for diameters smaller than 4 nm, whereas it is almost unchanged and equal to approximately 30± 10 GPa for diameters larger than 4 nm [50]. This value is comparable to the elastic modulus of graphite along the direction perpendicular to basal planes, Egraphite¼ 36 GPa [50]. Assuming the radial elastic modulus of CNTs equals 36 GPa, then sc are calculated to be 2.1 and 1.7 GPa by Equation (1). It has been reported that the elastic modulus of CNTs were decreased by irradiation because of induced point defects, especially vacancies [51,52]. Therefore, the actual compression stresses generated on the carbon layer in this study are considered to be smaller than 2.1 and 1.7 GPa.

sections.heading: 4.4. Formation mechanism of ion-irradiation-induced novel hybrid carbon nanomaterials
sections.text:
In the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs, new graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction inside the SiC tubular layer were formed after ion irradiation. Some studies have reported that platelet carbon nanofibers, which are stacked graphene nanosheets perpendicular to the fiber length direction, were synthesized using metal catalysis [22e25].
However, these platelet carbon nanofibers have no cylindrical MWCNTs. Wei et al. have reported that irradiating MWCNTs with 30-keV Ga ions leads to the inner shells folding into some pillboxlike nanocompartments inside the nanotubes [53]. It has also been reported that high-energy (MeV) ion irradiation of MWCNTs causes nano-compartments with a bamboo-like structure to be clearly formed inside the nanotubes [54]. The crystalline graphite wall structure of non-irradiated MWCNTs has been shown to be transformed to an amorphous carbon or finite-sized crystalline graphite structure [54]. Previous studies have shown some findings concerning the formation of carbon layers perpendicular to the nanotube length direction inside MWCNTs upon ion irradiation [53,54]. However, these produced carbon layers that were perpendicular to the nanotube length direction had discontinuous pillboxlike or amorphous bamboo-like structures [53,54]. Our results show that a novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial, consisting of continuous graphitic layers, perpendicular to the nanotube length direction inside cylindrical MWCNTs, has been successfully synthesized for the first time.
However, in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from typical cylindrical MWCNTs, new graphitic shells had not formed. This indicates that the inner slightly inclined graphitic shells to the radial direction are due to new graphitic shells being formed after ion irradiation. The average diameter of the new graphitic shells was 43.1± 1.8 nm, which was more than twice the average length of the inner slightly inclined graphitic shells of 16.0± 2.4 nm. This diameter equals the sum (40.5 nm) of the nanotube's inner diameter and twice the thickness of the inner slightly inclined graphitic shells. Microstructural developments to the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cupstacked MWCNTs, before and after ion irradiation, are schematically shown in Fig. 9. It is thereby considered that the new graphitic shells were formed by the following two processes: (1) bending of the inner slightly inclined graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction, and (2) a filling-in of the inner tube hollow by diffusing C atoms during ion irradiation. The corresponding schematics of microstructural developments to the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from typical cylindrical MWCNTs are shown in Fig. 10. The disorder in the carbon layer increased with increasing ion fluence, and the lattice plane spacing of graphitic shells also increased. The crystalline carbon layer was transformed into
amorphous carbon and finite-sized crystalline graphite structures with larger lattice plane spacing. The inner tube hollow was buried because of swelling from the carbon layer in the radial direction.
The microstructure of the novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial inside a SiC nanotube synthesized by irradiation are schematically shown in Fig. 11. This novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial
synthesized inside the amorphous SiC nanotubes consists of onedimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks with diameters less than 50 nm inside the cylindrical MWCNTs. The TEM image of the interface structure between these graphene nanodisks and cylindrical MWCNTs is shown in Fig. 3(c). The interface, as shown in Fig. 3(c), is partly equivocal in structure where it appears to be
orphous silicon carbide nanotube synthesized by ion irradiation. (For interpretation of this article.)
partly formed from the folding of inner graphitic shells by 90 . It is also appears partly dissevered from the inner surface of the cylindrical MWCNT. It is still unknown whether the edges of the dissevered graphene nanodisks are terminated with hydrogen or nitrogen, andwhether the edges of graphene nanodisks are bonded to C atoms of cylindrical MWCNTs. In the near future, the interface structure will be investigated circumstantially.
As aforementioned, the ion-irradiation-induced new structure of the carbon nanomaterial is controlled by the original structure of the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube before irradiation. This means that there is a possibility that only one-dimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks inside the SiC nanotube can be synthesized by irradiating the CeSiC coaxial nanotube with only inner slightly inclined graphitic shells (without cylindrical MWCNTs). Furthermore, the novel one-dimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks with an inner hole inside the SiC nanotube can be synthesized by irradiating a large caliber CeSiC coaxial nanotube. In addition, the ion irradiation of the CeSiC coaxial nanotube causes a high compression stress to be applied inside the nanotube because of the configuration change to the SiC nanotube. This high compression stressmay form a novel crystal phase and/or structure of nanomaterials inside the SiC nanotube. Thus, the ion irradiation of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes leads to novel microstructural development. By such means it is, therefore expected that many novel carbon nanomaterials can be synthesized by ion irradiation of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes. Because the new carbon nanomaterials are expected to have novel physical properties, this study has demonstrated that the synthetic process achieved through the ion irradiation technique will widen the application fields of carbon nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
Microstructural developments of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes under irradiation with 200-keV Si ions at room temperature were investigated by in situ TEM observation. The outer diameter of the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes increased with increasing ion fluence, whereas the inner diameter decreased, and the interior hole finally disappeared. The critical amorphization doses for SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes were larger than those found from previous studies on bulk SiC. The reason is considered to be that the induced point defects, elicited by the irradiation, may diffuse and be readily released from the surface and grain boundaries in the CeSiC coaxial nanotubes because of their larger specific surface area compared to the bulk counterpart. Despite the complete amorphization of SiC crystals, the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs was confirmed to have remained crystalline, even after the irradiation dose exceeded 20 dpa. Therefore, the carbon layer possessed better resistance against amorphization after ion irradiation, compared with the SiC layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube, because the sputtering of C atoms is restrained on the outer surface of the carbon layer and due to the compression stress, attributed to the SiC layer undergoing configurational change during irradiation. The lattice plane spacing of basal planes in the carbon layer increased up to the point of irradiation damage demonstrated by the complete amorphization of SiC crystals; afterwards it started to decrease. The compression stress generated on the carbon layer caused a decrease of lattice plane spacing of the basal planes in the carbon layer. The compression stress was calculated to be approximately 2 GPa. New graphitic shells perpendicular to the nanotube length direction suddenly emerged after ion irradiation in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube from cup-stacked MWCNTs. The inner slightly inclined graphitic shells to the radial direction are attributed to the formation of new graphitic shells after ion irradiation. A successful
synthesis of a novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial was achieved for the first time, which consisted of one-dimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks with diameters less than 50 nm, and cylindrical MWCNTs, inside an amorphous SiC nanotube. The ion-irradiationinduced new structured carbon nanomaterials can be controlled through the original structure of the carbon layer in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube before irradiation. Ion irradiation of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes therefore constitutes one of the new synthetic processes for making novel carbon nanomaterials.

metadata.abstractText: A novel hybrid carbon nanomaterial was synthesized by ion irradiation of a CeSiC coaxial nanotube. The hybrid consisted of one-dimensionally stacked graphene nanodisks with diameters less than 50 nm and cylindrical multiwalled carbon nanotubes inside an amorphous SiC tubular layer. A sudden emergence of new continuous graphitic layers in the microstructure were observed by in situ transmission electron microscopy following ion irradiation, where these layers were perpendicular to the nanotube's length direction. The SiC crystals in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube became amorphous, also due to the ion irradiation, although the critical amorphization dose was higher than that for bulk SiC. Most remarkably, the carbon layer remained crystalline, even after an irradiation dose higher than 20 dpa (displacement per atom). Such results show that these carbon layers possess better resistance against amorphization when subjected to ion irradiation than the SiC layers in the CeSiC coaxial nanotube. The lattice plane spacing of the carbon layer increases up to the point when irradiation damage lead to the complete amorphization of SiC crystals, after which it starts to decrease. This demonstrates that the carbon layer experiences high compression stress during ion irradiation. Thus, the ion irradiation of CeSiC coaxial nanotubes gives rise to a novel development of the microstructure and can be considered as one of the new synthetic processes for making novel carbon nanomaterials. © 2019 Acta Materialia Inc.
